description.hltext_display: Cooking on Deadline | How can slow cooking be the secret to a fast meal?
description.content:
The point is that, if a recipe calls for a little active preparation and then a lot of simmering, it can be a 20-minute meal even if it takes hours to cook. And that was the inspiration for this bold and rich roasted brisket with red wine jus.
If you can spare about 15 minutes a few hours before dinner, you can get this meal on the table with almost no effort. Here's how it works.
You start by bashing together fresh rosemary, garlic, salt and black peppercorns. That blend is rubbed over a brisket, which then is placed in a large Dutch oven. The meat is surrounded by mushroom caps, a quartered onion and a quartered pomegranate. Pop it in the oven and walk away.
When the brisket is done, you set it onto a plate to rest, spoon the mushrooms around it, then strain the liquid in the pot. And that's about it. The pomegranate breaks down during cooking, lending a deliciously tart-sweet flavor that complements the savory, salty flavor of the meat.
And all for about 20 minutes' effort.
Pomegranate-rosemary brisket with red wine jus
Start to finish: 2½ to 3 hours (20 minutes active).
1 tablespoon olive oil
1 tablespoon kosher salt
½ tablespoon whole peppercorns
2 sprigs fresh rosemary, leaves only
3 cloves garlic
2¼-pound brisket, trimmed of fat
8-ounce package baby portobello mushrooms
1 medium yellow onion, quartered
1 pomegranate, quartered
1 cup red wine
Heat the oven to 300. Drizzle the oil over the bottom of a large Dutch oven.
Using a mortar and pestle, spice grinder or small food processor, grind together the salt, peppercorns, rosemary and garlic until they form a coarse paste.
Rub the rosemary-garlic blend over the brisket, then place the meat in the Dutch oven. Scatter the mushrooms, onion and pomegranate around the meat, then pour the wine down the side. Cover the pot, and roast for 2 to 2½ hours, or until the meat is fork tender.
Transfer the brisket from the pot to a serving platter. Use a slotted spoon to transfer the mushrooms to the platter. Cover with foil and set aside.
Pour the liquid in the pot through a mesh strainer into a bowl. Discard the solids. Return the strained liquid to the pot and set over medium-high. Simmer until reduced and thickened, about 10 minutes. Serve the jus alongside the meat and mushrooms.
Serves 4.
Nutrition information per serving (values are rounded to the nearest whole number): 533 calories; 203 calories from fat (38 percent of total calories); 23 grams fat (7 grams saturated; 0 grams trans fats); 158 milligrams cholesterol; 14 grams carbohydrate; 55 grams protein; 1 gram fiber; 1,650 milligrams sodium.

description.hltext_display: S&P 500 companies more than double 3rd quarter buybacks
description.content:
BOSTON - Companies are using extra cash built up during the recession to repurchase stock, moves that are likely to please investors who see the value of their shares rise.
But the buyback surge may not please President Obama, who is urging companies to instead use surplus cash to hire more workers, hoping to generate jobs to sustain the economic recovery.
Standard & Poor's reported Monday that stock repurchases by S&P 500 companies more than doubled to $79.6 billion in the July-to-September period from $34.9 billion in last year's third quarter.
It was the fifth consecutive quarter of increasing buyback activity among the 500 largest publicly traded companies, many of them with substantial cash holdings built up during and after the recession that officially ended in mid-2009.
Stock buybacks indicate companies have enough cash to take their shares off the market, which increases the value of investors' remaining shares, and boosts per-share earnings results.
Buyback growth in the latest quarter "marks the full return of corporate participation in the equity markets," S&P analyst Howard Silverblatt said. "While we do not expect a return to the 2005-2007 buyback bonanza, we do see this as a strong, positive sign for the overall health of the market."
However, stock repurchases aren't rebounding as rapidly as they were earlier. The latest quarter's buyback figure is up just 3 percent from the second quarter's total of $77.6 billion. That's a significant slowdown from double-digit percentage increases in each of the preceding four quarter-to-quarter comparisons.
Obama met at the White House last week with 20 CEOs, urging corporate America to shake loose $1.9 trillion in untapped cash and create more jobs by hiring and investing in their businesses. Obama is trying to cut a national unemployment rate that rose to 9.8 percent in November and is slowing the broader economic recovery.
But many companies are reluctant to take cash off the sidelines, fearing consumer demand for the goods and services they provide is still too meager to support more hiring or capital spending. Companies also are reluctant to spend until the outlook for new government regulations becomes more clear. The latter worry could ease because of last week's congressional agreement to keep in place Bush era tax rates.
When companies build up cash from rising profits, their options include hiring more workers, investing in capital spending or acquisitions, buying back stock, and raising dividends paid to shareholders.
Many companies have been opting for the latter two, which please shareholders.
Much of the recent buyback surge has been driven by technology companies, which fared better than most corporations through the recession because they entered it with relatively little debt, and have seen demand for their products hold up. In the latest quarter, information technology companies, including Microsoft Corp., Hewlett-Packard Co. and IBM Corp., made up nearly 29 percent of all buybacks, up from 27 percent in the second quarter.
Wal-Mart Stores Inc. and Exxon Mobil Corp. were among the other names making large buybacks in the latest quarter.
Health care companies repurchased less stock, with their share of buybacks slipping to 13 percent in the third quarter from 19 percent in the second.
Silverblatt expects a slight overall increase in buybacks in the fourth quarter. For the first part of next year, he expects companies will continue to be cautious and refrain from purchasing an excessive amount of shares.
Dividend payouts by U.S. corporations also are expected to rise this year. Third-quarter dividend payouts totaled $51.3 billion for S&P 500 companies, and are nearly back to their first-quarter 2009 level of $51.7 billion.
But Silverblatt said last week that payouts likely won't return to 2008 levels until 2013.
More about 500
ARTICLE: Little gets new position with Hagadone Hospitality
More about Billion
ARTICLE: Eurozone says bailout funds enough ... for now
ARTICLE: Merck 3Q profit plunges 90 percent

description.hltext_display: Denver BBQ baron Louis Wolfe is packing up his smoker
description.author: Douglas Brown
description.content:
He doesn't gush about the provenance of his hickory, or lecture patrons on the herbal nuances of the homemade barbecue sauce.
Nor does Louis Wolfe, who opened Wolfe's Barbecue on East Colfax Avenue 25 years ago, broadcast tweets about his livelihood to the world ("Just placed a rack of ribs in the smoker!"), or fill a blog with musings about the state of brisket, or seek "Likes" on Facebook.
What he does, for the most part, is smoke meat and tofu. And sell it. One guy alone, as he puts it, "hour after hour, day after day, month after month, year after year" doing the same thing.
Lucky us.
But our good fortune is about to end. Wolfe, 66, is shuttering his barbecue joint the day after Christmas.
"It's As he has done most days for the past quarter century, Louis Wolfe turns on his "open" sign at 11:30 a.m. at his East Colfax barbeque joint. (Photos: Cyrus McCrimmon, The Denver Post )time," he said on a recent morning in the restaurant's orderly, small, spare kitchen, as he prepared for the lunch and dinner crowds. "I describe my coming time as a time to reinvent myself we'll see what the tinkering will bring about."
Denverites will miss Wolfe's for the barbecue itself, which is excellent (and vegetarians should be especially crestfallen Wolfe has smoked tofu in his restaurant since just days after he opened).
But they'll also lament the passing of something less tangible, a quality nobody can buy or engineer or draw up in a business plan an atmosphere unto itself, borne out of the toil and the constant presence of the curmudgeonly, intellectual character who has been responsible for the restaurant's every last detail. Wolfe mopped the floors and supplied the napkins. He hung the pictures on the walls, made the lemon pie and the coleslaw and the beans, cleaned the tables, and bought the hickory in sacks from King Soopers.
The domain that sprouted around him 800 square feet of red-and- white checked tablecloths, and a deeply blackened custom smoker, and a worn plank floor that creaks, and walls plastered with Colorado paraphernalia, and ever-present jumbles Wolfe batters ribs with sauce just outside the smoker. ( | )of newspapers, and constant public radio station broadcasts, and the counter, into which Wolfe usually leans when people place orders will become a meeting space for his landlord, the nearby Basilica of the Immaculate Conception.
Wolfe's new world will include his beloved blue Geo Metro convertible, a tent (he wants to camp, using Depression- era guidebooks written through the Federal Writers Project, several of which he keeps in his restaurant kitchen), and his Park Hill apartment, located just a toss from Colfax Avenue.
Living and working beside the road, which Wolfe champions, is "like being on a riverbank," he says.
Wolfe grew up on another river the Arkansas, in Great Bend, Kan., in a barbecue-happy household (one 1954 picture on the wall, taken by a young Wolfe, portrays his aproned father standing before the expansive, backyard grill).
A job with the American Friends Service Committee an organization dedicated to social justice and humanitarian relief brought him from Kansas to Denver. But a love for barbecue, and annual success catering Passover seders hosted by his synagogue, persuaded him at age 40 that he didn't want to spend the rest of his working life doing paperwork; he wanted to make the kind of food he grew up with.
Ever since, "it's been 12- to 14-hour days of moving around, which is good," said Wolfe, a white-bearded, slight guy with a professorial way about him often, for extended periods, he closes his eyes while he's talking, giving him the appearance of a philosopher searching for just the right point to make.
Wolfe's, sitting between the State Capitol and the basilica, attracts all sorts, from pin-striped lobbyists to people who tug shopping carts around with them. Many are regulars.
"Thank you, Mr. Wolfe," said Ben Kennedy, 21, a Denverite who visits the restaurant every month or so, after finishing his beef brisket sandwich and baked beans. "We're going to miss you."
Besides the food, Kennedy likes that the place is "distinctly Wolfe's," he said. "Not a lot of places have the home-style vibe. It's so soothing to be here, to eat the food, to listen to the music."
The departure of the restaurant is "the loss of what Denver really was, not what it's becoming," said James Fox, 40, a Capitol Hill software salesman who was examining the historic photographs on the restaurant walls after a late lunch. "I grew up in Lamar, and this is what I grew up with, places like this. Now there are too many fast-food places, fewer places where you can walk in and talk to the owner."
You couldn't eat at Wolfe's without encountering the owner. Not only was he always there, but with the exception of just a few months after he opened, in 1985, he has been the sole person working in the restaurant.
Early on, he said, he realized it would be difficult to keep the place going while paying salaries. So he just did everything himself. When he took vacation, he put a sign on the door. If he couldn't be there, nobody was enjoying smoked tofu sandwiches.
Over time, he said, he understood the all-encompassing experience was "like keeping house all day."
"Lots of different tasks," he said. "One is better at some than others, but you get them all done."
Wolfe's exit from running a restaurant doesn't mean he won't still enjoy sitting down before plates of smoked chicken and little bowls of potato salad (Wolfe tried to always use Colorado red potatoes). He has eaten ribs and vinegary coleslaw and beans and the rest of the barbecue canon all his life.
"Barbecue is primordial," he said. "It brings us back to that very first moment of fire and raw meat."
He doesn't envision taking barbecue tours of the nation, with stops in Kansas City, the Hill Country of Texas, and Memphis. But for the first time in decades, he does believe he will travel a bit, go to a gym, and do a lot of reading.
"I'm going from not much money and no time," he said, "to not much money and a lot of time."
He added: "It's been a good run. I've had the pleasure of doing what I wanted to do."
Douglas Brown: 303-954-1395 or djbrown@denverpost.com

description.hltext_display: You are born to win, Sagittarius
description.content:
TODAY'S BIRTHDAY (Dec. 22). You'll move up in the world. Authority figures who once challenged you will extol your virtues. Relationships are smooth going into 2011, and you'll have wonderful times with friends and family. In January, you'll use your power to help someone attain what you have. There's a trip in March and a windfall in October. Libra and Scorpio people adore you. Your lucky numbers are: 30, 11, 3, 33 and 18.
ARIES (March 21-April 19). Today's luck is subtle. You have to be both mature and imaginative to see it. You will get the chance at an opportunity that never was available to your parents. Seize it.
TAURUS (April 20-May 20). Small steps would normally get you from point "A" to point "B" — but not today. What's necessary is a running leap. Anything less won't get you to the finish.
GEMINI (May 21-June 21). Unfinished business is too heavy of a mental weight. You can't be happy and creative with this load on your mind. Tie up loose ends. Afterward, you'll feel refreshed and ready for a new start.
CANCER (June 22-July 22). You are a favorite playmate of the universe.
This is not about pranks and mischief. Today's game is vigorous and challenging and will engage your body and mind.
LEO (July 23-Aug. 22). Your meetings will be more important than you realize. Give yourself twice as much time to get ready as you normally would, and spend a good deal of that time psyching yourself up.
VIRGO (Aug. 23-Sept. 22). You paid your dues. You obeyed authority, served the boss and put in your time doing thankless tasks. And though the work was considered lowly, the rewards were high. You stand tall today because of it.
LIBRA (Sept. 23-Oct. 23). You are used to enjoying yourself — some days less than others. In those instances, the remedy is simple. If you want to live a life of higher quality, give a greater level of attention to your endeavors.
SCORPIO (Oct. 24-Nov. 21). Better to do one thing completely today than to attempt many and leave them unfinished. It will bring you good fortune and deep satisfaction to do so.
SAGITTARIUS (Nov. 22-Dec. 21). You will be amazed at the people who find success more challenging than failure. You, on the other hand, take to winning like you were born to do it. Indeed, you were.
CAPRICORN (Dec. 22-Jan. 19). Your ability to concentrate in spite of distractions is impressive. External events will be more easily ignored than internal mental chatter, but you shut out both in favor of finishing something that is very important to you.
AQUARIUS (Jan. 20-Feb. 18). Your perspective is different from how others experience life. Right now, the small details seem as bright and close as the large issues. You must distance yourself in order to decide what is truly important.
PISCES (Feb. 19-March 20). You tend to value the things that take a good deal of effort. But something you do effortlessly is of great value to another person. Recognize what it is, and deliver it to the one who needs it. This is how you'll make a difference.

description.hltext_display: How to replace a doorbell
description.author: Helium members
description.content:
Having your doorbell stop working, or worse moving to a new place and finding you cant stand the sound of the doorbell, is a bummer, but luckily, if you know how to work a screwdriver, they are not that hard to replace.
First an overview so you know what youre getting into. Replacing your doorbell means youll have to go to the store and buy a new one. Then, once you have it, youll need to open and undo the wires in your current doorbell, take it out, then put the wires on the new doorbell, and then screw it back in. Really, its just that simple. The details arent much harder. First, go to the store and pick out a doorbell, make sure you like it so you wont have to do all this over again in a few weeks.
Back home first turn off the electricity or at least the part the goes to your doorbell, then approach your doorbell with your mission in mind. Examine your doorbell, they all have a cover of some sort which surrounds the actual button. Some have a plate that snaps off, others have screws. If it snaps off, do just that, if it has screws, then you will need to unscrew those to get at the insides of your doorbell.
Either way, your doorbell should be exposed; though if you had a snap on cover, you will likely have to remove the screws that are inside to free the doorbell from its housing.
When you pull on the doorbell, notice that it is connected to wires, these need to be disconnected from the doorbell. Most of them will have little screws for keeping them in place, others little clips. Either way the outcome should be the same, disconnect the wires from the doorbell. Once you do, the doorbell should drop into your hand, leaving you with no doorbell for your home.
Pick up your new doorbell and see if the connector types are the same as the ones that were in your old doorbell, if so, simply connect them just as they were before. If not, you might have to strip the wires to insert them, or clip them in. If so, there will likely be instructions that come with the doorbell.
Once you have the wires on, all thats left is to push the doorbell back into its repository and then either screw or click the faceplate back over it.
And that should do it. Dont forget to turn the power back on before testing, or youll think youve failed.
